raw_text:
IN THE CIRCUIT COURT OF TALLAPOOSA COUNTY
CHRISTOPHER BLAINE MCGREGOR,
Respondent,
CASE NO.: 70-DR-23-900051.00
v.
BRITTANY MICHELLE GILLILAND,
Petitioner.
PETITIONER’S FIRST SET OF CONSOLIDATED DISCOVERY REQUESTS
COMES NOW, Petitioner, BRITTANY MICHELLE GILLILAND (hereinafter
“Mother”), by and through the undersigned counsel of record, Barbara H. Agricola and Matthew
A. Holdren, and propounds the following Interrogatories, Requests for Production of Documents,
and Requests for Admission to the Respondent, CHRISTOPHER BLAINE MCGREGOR
(hereinafter “Father”), pursuant to Rules 33, 34, and 36 of the Alabama Rules of Civil Procedure.
Preliminary Statement and Definitions:
The following Preliminary Statement and Definitions apply to each of the Interrogatories set
forth hereunder and they are deemed to be incorporated therein.
A. The terms “you” and “your,” as they are used herein, refer to Respondent, and include any
and all agents, servants, and employees to Respondent including, but not limited to,
Respondent’s lawyer(s) and to any other person or persons acting pursuant to Respondent’s
direction.
B. The singular number and the masculine gender, as used herein, shall be deemed to include
the plural, the feminine, or the neuter, as may be appropriate.
C. The term “person” as used herein, shall be deemed to include, in the plural as well as
singular, any natural person, firm, association, partnership, joint venture, corporation or
other legal entity unless the context is otherwise indicated.
D. If you are asked to identify a person, please state for each such person:
• That person’s full name;
• If that person is other than a natural person (e.g., corporation, partnership, etc.), the
type of entity it is;
• That person’s last known home address and the telephone number;
• If the person is a natural person, his/her relationship (including business, blood or
Brittany Michelle Gilliland v. Christopher Blaine McGregor
Circuit Court of Tallapoosa County
Case No.: 70-DR-23-900051.00
Petitioner’s First Set of Consolidated Discovery Requests
Page 1 of 9
other relationship), if any, to you.
E. The term “document” as used herein, shall mean originals and all copies unless identical,
of written, recorded and graphic matter, produced or reproduced, formal or informal,
whether for internal or external use, including but not limited to correspondence, letters,
memoranda, drafts, corporate minutes, notes, minutes, lists of persons or things, books,
charge cards, cancelled checks, mechanical and electrical sound recording, bonuses,
retirement benefits, savings plans, stock options, and video tapes.
F. These interrogatories call for all information (including information contained in writing)
known or available to you, including all information in the possession of your attorneys,
accountants, employees and/or their firms, corporations and other persons acting on your
behalf or under your control.
G. If you cannot answer any interrogatory fully, after exercising due diligence to make
inquiries and secure the information requested, please so state and answer each
interrogatory to the extent you deem possible, specifying the portion of the interrogatory
you claim you are unable to answer fully and completely and specifying the facts upon
which you rely to support your contention that you are unable to answer the interrogatory
fully and completely and state with knowledge, information, or belief you have concerning
the unanswered portion of such interrogatory.
H. These interrogatories are continuing in character so as to require you to file supplemental
answers and responses of you obtain further or different information before trial as required
by the Alabama Rules of Civil Procedure.
These interrogatories are to be answered under oath in writing and said written answers
under oath are to be served upon Petitioner ’s counsel, Barbara H. Agricola and Matthew A.
Holdren, 127 South 8th Street, Opelika, Alabama 36801, within thirty (30) days of receipt of these
interrogatories, pursuant to Rule 33 of the Alabama Rules of Civil Procedure. These discovery
requests are continuing in nature and are due to be supplemented should any answers change and/or
need to be supplemented. If such supplementation and/or changes becomes necessary, it is the
responsibility of the answering party to take whatever action to provide said
changes/supplementation to Agricola Law, LLC.
Additionally, these discovery requests are requests to produce copies and therefore, any
costs for such production shall be reimbursed by Agricola Law, LLC. This means that an answer
to any discovery request which makes the requested information/documents available for
inspection shall be treated as a failure to respond since these are requests to produce, not make
available for inspection and therefore, the next appropriate steps will be taken to compel the
production and/or response to said discovery requests answered in any fashion wherein it does not
comply with these requests to produce.
Brittany Michelle Gilliland v. Christopher Blaine McGregor
Circuit Court of Tallapoosa County
Case No.: 70-DR-23-900051.00
Petitioner’s First Set of Consolidated Discovery Requests
Page 2 of 9
INTERROGATORIES
1. Describe in detail each instance since February 27, 2024, in which you did not allow the
Petitioner-Mother, Brittany Michelle Gilliland, her scheduled visitation rights with the minor
children A.K. and B.M.
Response:
2. List all communications you have had with the children's school or educational institution
concerning Brittany Gilliland, and provide the content of such communications.
Response:
3. Please detail any reasons and the factual basis for why you prevented Brittany Gilliland from
picking up A.K. from school as stipulated in the Final Decree of Divorce.
Response:
4. Please describe any instances where you have accused Brittany Gilliland of mental instability
or suggested to any individual, including the minor children, that she is mentally unstable.
Response:
5. State the name and address of all persons having substantive knowledge relating to this matter
and identify whether or not you intend to use those persons at any proceeding in this matter as
witnesses or as an expert witness, including to what you expect each witness will testify and if
as an expert witness, list the expert’s name, address, the subject matter of the testimony on
which the expert is expected to testify, the substance of facts and opinions to which the expert
is expected to testify, and a summary of the grounds for each opinion offered.
Response:
6. List in detail all documents and other physical evidence which you may use in preparation or
at any of the proceedings of this cause including any pictures of an explicit nature or otherwise,
regardless of whether you intend to use it at the trial in this action. This includes anything
related to rebuttal or impeachment.
Response:
7. Please state all facts that support your accusations made against Brittany Gilliland of causing
physical harm to A.K. or any of the minor children.
Response:
Brittany Michelle Gilliland v. Christopher Blaine McGregor
Circuit Court of Tallapoosa County
Case No.: 70-DR-23-900051.00
Petitioner’s First Set of Consolidated Discovery Requests
Page 3 of 9
8. If you have conducted any surveillance, including but not limited to electronic surveillance
(electronic surveillance being defined as the interception of any voice communication made
by the Petitioner by electronically recording the same or by listening in on any voice
communication made by the Petitioner), of the Petitioner, or had any person or persons conduct
such surveillance on your behalf, then state what surveillance you have conducted, including
the date, time and place of such surveillance, the method employed for such surveillance, the
person conducting such surveillance, including the name and address of such person, whether
said surveillance was recorded, whether a written transcript or report have been made of such
surveillance, and the details of what was observed and/or the details of the conversations that
were intercepted or recorded, regardless of whether you intend to use such documentation
at trial. This includes anything related to rebuttal or impeachment.
Response:
9. Please state all facts that support your accusations made against Brittany Gilliland for violating
the divorce decree.
Response:
10. Please provide a detailed list of the personal property items you have failed to distribute to
Brittany Gilliland per the Final Decree of Divorce, including but not limited to wall décor,
bedroom lamps, memory boxes, and clothing.
Response:
11. Please explain any instances in which you have signed Brittany Gilliland’s name on financial
documents or checks without her express authorization. Provide dates and details of the
documents.
Response:
12. Please state what positive and negative qualities you feel the Petitioner has as a parent.
Response:
13. Please state the last-known date that A.K., a Minor Child, engaged in visitation with Mother,
pursuant to the original Divorce Decree. Please provide explanations for specific instances
where Mother was denied visitation, if there are such instances.
Response:
Brittany Michelle Gilliland v. Christopher Blaine McGregor
Circuit Court of Tallapoosa County
Case No.: 70-DR-23-900051.00
Petitioner’s First Set of Consolidated Discovery Requests
Page 4 of 9
14. Please state whether you have paid Mother her required equity payments owed on your prior
marital residence, the amount paid, and which dates, since the execution of your original
Divorce Decree.
Response:
15. Please state any instances where the Department of Human Resources has gotten involved in
a case regarding the Minor Children, what prompted the investigation, and the conclusion of
the DHR matter.
Response:
16. Please list all social media accounts with names/handles/usernames (e.g. Facebook, Instagram,
snapchat).
Response:
17. Are you aware that your answers to these interrogatories are made under oath, are continuing
in nature, and may be used as material testimony at any and all proceedings?
Response:
18. Please state each and every person who assisted you in answering these interrogatories and
whether you are aware that your answers to these interrogatories are given under oath.
Response:
REQUESTS FOR PRODUCTION
The requested documents are to be produced and require the answering party to provide
copies and/or duplicates of the same to be served upon Barbara H. Agricola and Matthew A.
Holdren, 127 South 8th Street, Opelika, Alabama 36801, within thirty (30) days of receipt of these
requests for production of documents, pursuant to Rule 34 of the Alabama Rules of Civil
Procedure.
The requests for production shall be deemed continuous so as to require seasonable
supplemental answers if the Defendant obtains further information between the time of answering
these interrogatories and the time of the trial of this action. If such supplementation and/or changes
become necessary, it is the responsibility of the answering party to take whatever action to provide
said changes/supplementation to Agricola Law, LLC.
1. Please provide documents or communications demonstrating the reasons for any denial of
visitation rights to Brittany Gilliland since February 27, 2024.
Response:
Brittany Michelle Gilliland v. Christopher Blaine McGregor
Circuit Court of Tallapoosa County
Case No.: 70-DR-23-900051.00
Petitioner’s First Set of Consolidated Discovery Requests
Page 5 of 9
2. Please provide all correspondence, emails, texts, and written notes between you and the
children’s school or educational institutions regarding Brittany Gilliland.
Response:
3. Please provide any recordings, videos, or other electronic evidence that demonstrates
interactions between you and the minor children wherein Brittany Gilliland was discussed.
Response:
4. All documents evidencing payments made for child support, alimony, shared debts, and/or
other financial obligations as ordered in the Final Decree of Divorce.
Response:
5. Produce copies of all photos, videos, CDs or other evidence you have in this case, even if
you do not plan on using it at trial or any other proceeding of this action. This includes
any rebuttal and/or impeachment evidence.
Response:
6. Please provide photographic or video evidence of the condition and location of the disputed
personal property items that were to be distributed to Brittany Gilliland as per the divorce
decree.
Response:
7. Please provide any and all bank statements, passbooks, certificates of deposit, or other
written memoranda of any kind and description reflecting ownership by you in whole or in
part, legal or equitable, of any savings account or bank account or account in any financial
institution, including, but not limited to, savings and loan associations, credit unions, banks
or accounts maintained with any brokerage firm from the last three years.
Response:
8. Please provide any and all documentation to support your response to Interrogatory # 3,
including any and all documents touching, concerning, or relating to your net worth,
including, but not limited to, personal financial statement and loan applications filed with
or provided to any person, corporation, business, financial institution, or government
agency from January 1, 2019 to the date of trial.
Response:
Brittany Michelle Gilliland v. Christopher Blaine McGregor
Circuit Court of Tallapoosa County
Case No.: 70-DR-23-900051.00
Petitioner’s First Set of Consolidated Discovery Requests
Page 6 of 9
REQUESTS FOR ADMISSIONS
The requested responses are to be admitted or denied and shall be served upon Petitioner’s
Counsel, Barbara H. Agricola and Matthew A. Holdren, 127 South 8th Street, Opelika, Alabama
36801, within thirty (30) days of receipt of these requests for admissions, pursuant to Rule 36 of
the Alabama Rules of Civil Procedure.
The requests for admission shall be deemed continuous so as to require seasonable
supplemental answers if the Defendant obtains further information between the time of answering
these requests and the time of the trial of this action. If such supplementation and/or changes
become necessary, it is the responsibility of the answering party to take whatever action to provide
said changes/supplementation to Agricola Law, LLC.
1. Admit that items belonging to Mother, and outlined in the original Divorce Decree,
have been purposefully withheld from her.
Admit Deny
2. Admit that you have blocked Mother’s phone number in the past on Minor Children’s
phones.
Admit Deny
3. Admit that Mother has been excluded from relevant group communication pertaining
to the Minor Children’s extra-curricular activities.
Admit Deny
4. Admit that you have willfully interfered with Mother’s ability to attend extra-curricular
and special events, for example, by either relaying incorrect information regarding said
events, or neglecting to inform Mother of said events in its entirety.
Admit Deny
5. Admit that Minor Children have, on multiple occasions, shared the same bed as their
paternal grandmother’s partner, who is not related to the Minor Children by blood or
marriage.
Admit Deny
6. Admit that you have made derogatory comments about Mother in the presence of Minor
Children.
Admit Deny
Brittany Michelle Gilliland v. Christopher Blaine McGregor
Circuit Court of Tallapoosa County
Case No.: 70-DR-23-900051.00
Petitioner’s First Set of Consolidated Discovery Requests
Page 7 of 9
7. Admit that you have denied Brittany Gilliland her court-ordered visitation rights since
February 27, 2024.
Admit Deny
8. Admit that you have intentionally provided misinformation to school officials
regarding Brittany Gilliland's right to visit or pick up A.K. from school.
Admit Deny
9. Admit that you have signed Brittany Gilliland’s name on any financial document or
check without her authorization.
Admit Deny
10. Admit that you have failed to distribute the personal property items as ordered in the
Final Decree of Divorce.
Admit Deny
11. Admit that you have alienated the minor children against Brittany Gilliland through
verbal comments and actions.
Admit Deny
12. Admit that you have failed to consult with Brittany Gilliland on significant decisions
affecting the children's health, education, and welfare.
Admit Deny
Respectfully submitted on June 24, 2024.
/s/ Barbara H. Agricola (AGR004)
/s/ Matthew A. Holdren
Counsel for Petitioner
OF COUNSEL:
AGRICOLA LAW
127 South 8th Street
Opelika, Alabama 36801
Brittany Michelle Gilliland v. Christopher Blaine McGregor
Circuit Court of Tallapoosa County
Case No.: 70-DR-23-900051.00
Petitioner’s First Set of Consolidated Discovery Requests
Page 8 of 9
Telephone: 334.759.7557

matt@agricolalaw.com
www.agricolalaw.com
CERTIFICATE OF SERVICE
This is to certify that I have this day served the following with a copy of the foregoing, by
electronic filing in the AlaCourt E-File System and/or by placing same in an envelope, properly
addressed, and depositing it in the United States Mail, with adequate postage prepaid on June 24,
2024.
Thomas Fredrick Young
Attorney for Respondent
P.O. Box 1160
Alex City, Alabama 35011
tyoung@mhhlaw.net
/s/ Barbara H. Agricola
OF COUNSEL
Brittany Michelle Gilliland v. Christopher Blaine McGregor
